originalNote:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 Dennis Martin is a pleasant 46-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right heel pain. The onset of his pain began 10 days ago while training for a triathlon. He locates his pain to the posterior aspect of his heel, which radiates proximally into his calf. His pain is aggravated by working out and when he first gets up in the morning. If he sits for a long period, his pain will return upon standing. The patient states that he runs 10 kilometers in the morning. At lunchtime, he tries to get on a bike for about 45 minutes to an hour. In the evening, he goes to the aquatic center and swims for 30 minutes to 1 hour. The patient states that he runs 5 days per week. He adds that he alternates between a long run and a long bike ride on weekends. He currently takes one day off from his exercises. The patient states that he does not stretch at all. He denies any left leg pain.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 Musculoskeletal: Reports right heel pain. Denies left leg pain.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAM
 
 MSK: Examination of the right heel: Pain with resisted extension. Mild pain with flexion. Positive calcaneal squeeze test. Severe tenderness to the Achilles tendon. Thompson test is negative, bilaterally.
 
 RESULTS
 
 No new imaging was obtained today
 
 ASSESSMENT
 
 Right Achilles tendinitis.
 
 PLAN
 
 After reviewing the patient's examination today, I had a lengthy discussion with the patient regarding his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his symptoms are likely secondary to overuse. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. The patient was instructed to take at least 1 week off from his training to recover from this. I will provide him with a referral for formal physical therapy to strengthen his right lower extremities. I have advised him to take 3 tablets of ibuprofen every 6 hours for pain. If his pain does not improve with physical therapy, I will recommend obtaining an x-ray.
 
 INSTRUCTIONS
 
 The patient will follow up with me in 7 to 10 days to check on his progress.

تاریخِ مرضِ حال
 
ڈینیس مارٹن ایک خوش مزاج 46 سالہ مرد ہیں جو آج کلینک میں دائیں پنڈلی کے درد کی تشخیص کے لیے آئے ہیں۔ ان کے درد کی ابتدا 10 دن پہلے ٹرائی ایتھلون کی تربیت کے دوران ہوئی تھی۔ وہ اپنے درد کو پنڈلی کے پچھلے حصے میں محسوس کرتے ہیں، جو پنڈلی کی طرف بڑھتا ہے۔ ورزش کرنے اور صبح جب وہ پہلی بار اٹھتے ہیں تو ان کا درد بڑھ جاتا ہے۔ اگر وہ طویل عرصے تک بیٹھے رہتے ہیں، تو درد کھڑے ہونے پر واپس آ جاتا ہے۔ مریض کا بیان ہے کہ وہ صبح 10 کلومیٹر دوڑتے ہیں۔ دوپہر کے کھانے کے وقت، وہ تقریباً 45 منٹ سے ایک گھنٹے تک بائیک پر جانے کی کوشش کرتے ہیں۔ شام کو، وہ آبی مرکز جاتے ہیں اور 30 منٹ سے 1 گھنٹے تک تیراکی کرتے ہیں۔ مریض کا بیان ہے کہ وہ ہفتے میں 5 دن دوڑتے ہیں۔ انہوں نے مزید کہا کہ وہ ہفتے کے آخر میں لمبی دوڑ اور لمبی بائیک سواری کے درمیان متبادل کرتے ہیں۔ فی الحال وہ اپنی ورزش سے ایک دن کی چھٹی لیتے ہیں۔ مریض کا بیان ہے کہ وہ بالکل بھی stretching نہیں کرتے ہیں۔ وہ کسی بھی بائیں پاؤں کے درد سے انکار کرتے ہیں۔

جسمانی نظام کا جائزہ
 
مسکلو اسکلٹل: دائیں پنڈلی کے درد کی رپورٹ۔ بائیں پاؤں کے درد سے انکار۔

جسمانی معائنہ
 
MSK: دائیں پنڈلی کا معائنہ: مزاحمت کے ساتھ توسیع پر درد۔ ہلکا درد flexion کے ساتھ۔ مثبت calcaneal squeeze test۔ Achilles tendon میں شدید درد۔ Thompson test دونوں طرف منفی ہے۔

نتائج
 
آج کوئی نئی امیجنگ نہیں کی گئی۔

تشخیص
 
دائیں Achilles tendinitis۔

منصوبہ
 
آج مریض کے معائنے کا جائزہ لینے کے بعد، میں نے اس کے موجودہ علامات کے بارے میں مریض کے ساتھ لمبی گفتگو کی۔ میں نے انہیں بتایا کہ ان کے علامات زیادہ استعمال کے ثانوی ہونے کا امکان ہے۔ میں نے تجویز دی ہے کہ ہم مریض کا علاج conservative طریقے سے کریں۔ مریض کو اس سے صحت یاب ہونے کے لیے کم سے کم 1 ہفتے کی تربیت سے وقفہ کرنے کی ہدایت کی گئی۔ میں ان کے دائیں نچلے اعضاء کو مضبوط کرنے کے لیے رسمی physical therapy کے لیے ایک ریفرل فراہم کروں گا۔ میں نے انہیں درد کے لیے ہر 6 گھنٹے میں 3 گولیاں ibuprofen لینے کا مشورہ دیا۔ اگر ان کا درد physical therapy سے بہتر نہیں ہوتا ہے، تو میں x-ray لینے کی سفارش کروں گا۔

ہدایات
 
مریض 7 سے 10 دنوں میں ان کی پیشرفت کی جانچ کے لیے مجھ سے follow-up کریں گے۔

originalNote:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
 
 Bilateral knee pain.
 
 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 Sophia Jackson is a pleasant 30-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of bilateral knee pain. She was referred by her primary care provider. The onset of her pain began 6 months ago. She denies any specific injury. The patient describes her pain as a deep, achy pain. She locates her pain to the posterior aspect of her patellae. The patient also reports â€œcreakingâ€ in her knees. She denies any swelling or redness in her knees. Her pain is aggravated by transitioning from a seated position to standing as well as ascending and descending stairs. Her pain is alleviated by rest. The patient has been icing her knees and wrapping her knees with an ACE bandage. She also takes ibuprofen or Aleve occasionally for pain. She states she tries to be as active as she can. She enjoys running outdoors. The patient adds that she would run 5 to 6 miles per day; however, she is unable to go 0.5 miles secondary to the pain. She denies any previous injuries to her knees.
 
 She works from home.
 
 MEDICAL HISTORY
 
 Patient reports history of an upper extremity fracture when she was in 6th grade.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 Musculoskeletal: Reports bilateral knee pain and crepitus. Denies swelling or redness in the bilateral knees.
 
 VITALS
 
 All vital signs are within the normal limits.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAM
 
 GAIT: Normal, no deformity present.
 CV: Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.
 No edema
 NEURO: Patella and Achilles reflexes are symmetrical.
 MSK: Examination of the bilateral lower extremities: Abduction strength is 3/5. Remainder of muscle strength is 5/5. Examination of the bilateral knees: No overlying erythema, ecchymosis, or warmth of the skin appreciated. No effusion. Tenderness to palpation of the bilateral retinaculum. Positive patellar grind test. Knee pain with squatting. Negative Lachman test bilaterally. Negative anterior and posterior drawer tests bilaterally. Negative McMurray test bilaterally.
 
 RESULTS
 
 X-rays of the bilateral knees were reviewed today. These demonstrate no evidence of any fractures or osteoarthritis.
 
 ASSESSMENT
 
 Bilateral knee patellofemoral pain syndrome.
 
 PLAN
 
 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient regarding her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with patellofemoral pain syndrome. We discussed treatment options and I have recommended that we begin with conservative treatment in the form of formal physical therapy to increase her lower extremity strength, mobility, and correct any incorrect running mechanics. I encouraged her to take running easy for now. She can continue taking ibuprofen or anti-inflammatories as needed for pain. All questions were answered.
 
 INSTRUCTIONS
 
 The patient will follow up with me soon.

شکایتِ اصلی

دونوں گھٹنوں میں درد۔

عارضی مرض کی تاریخ

صوفیا جیکسن ایک خوش مزاج 30 سالہ خاتون ہیں جو آج کلینک میں دونوں گھٹنوں کے درد کے جائزے کے لیے آئی ہیں۔ انھیں ان کے پرائمری کیئر فراہم کنندہ نے بھیجا ہے۔ ان کے درد کا آغاز 6 ماہ پہلے ہوا۔ انھوں نے کسی خاص چوٹ سے انکار کیا۔ مریض اپنے درد کو گہرا، دردناک درد کے طور پر بیان کرتی ہے۔ وہ اپنے درد کو پٹیلا کے پچھلے حصے میں محسوس کرتی ہیں۔ مریض کو اپنے گھٹنوں میں "کریکنگ" کی بھی شکایت ہے۔ وہ اپنے گھٹنوں میں سوجن یا سرخی سے انکار کرتی ہیں۔ ان کا درد بیٹھنے کی حالت سے کھڑے ہونے اور سیڑھیاں چڑھنے اور اترنے سے بڑھ جاتا ہے۔ ان کے درد کو آرام سے راحت ملتی ہے۔ مریض اپنے گھٹنوں پر برف لگا رہی ہیں اور اپنے گھٹنوں کو ACE بینڈیج سے باندھ رہی ہیں۔ وہ درد کے لیے کبھی کبھار ibuprofen یا Aleve بھی لیتی ہیں۔ وہ کہتی ہیں کہ وہ جتنا ہو سکے اتنی ہی سرگرم رہنے کی کوشش کرتی ہیں۔ انھیں باہر دوڑنا پسند ہے۔ مریض نے بتایا کہ وہ روزانہ 5 سے 6 میل دوڑتی تھیں؛ تاہم، درد کی وجہ سے وہ 0.5 میل بھی نہیں چل پاتیں۔ وہ اپنے گھٹنوں پر کوئی سابقہ ​​چوٹ نہیں مانتیں۔

وہ گھر سے کام کرتی ہیں۔

طبی تاریخ

مریض نے بتایا کہ چھٹی جماعت میں ان کی اوپری لِمب میں فریکچر ہوا تھا۔

اعضاء کا جائزہ

مسکلو اسکلٹل: دونوں گھٹنوں میں درد اور کرپیٹس کی رپورٹ۔ دونوں گھٹنوں میں سوجن یا سرخی سے انکار۔

وائٹلز

تمام وائٹل سائن معمول کی حد میں ہیں۔

جسمانی معائنہ

چلنے کا انداز: معمول، کوئی خرابی موجود نہیں ہے۔
CV: دل کی سماعت: باقاعدہ رفتار اور تال۔ کوئی مرمور نہیں۔
کوئی edema نہیں
NEURO: پٹیلا اور Achilles reflexes ہم آہنگ ہیں۔
MSK: دونوں نچلے اعضاء کا معائنہ: ابڈکشن کی طاقت 3/5 ہے۔ بقیہ پٹھوں کی طاقت 5/5 ہے۔ دونوں گھٹنوں کا معائنہ: جلد پر کوئی سرخ، ایکیموسس یا گرمی محسوس نہیں ہوئی۔ کوئی effusion نہیں۔ دونوں retinaculum کے palpation پر حساسیت۔ مثبت پٹیلر گرائنڈ ٹیسٹ۔ اسکواٹنگ کے ساتھ گھٹنے کا درد۔ دونوں طرف منفی Lachman ٹیسٹ۔ دونوں طرف منفی anterior اور posterior drawer ٹیسٹ۔ دونوں طرف منفی McMurray ٹیسٹ۔

نتائج

دونوں گھٹنوں کے X-rays کا آج جائزہ لیا گیا۔ ان میں کسی بھی فریکچر یا osteoarthritis کا کوئی ثبوت نہیں ملا۔

تشخیص

دونوں گھٹنوں کا پٹیلوفیمورل درد سنڈروم۔

منصوبہ

مریض کے معائنے اور ریڈیوگرافک نتائج کا جائزہ لینے کے بعد، میں نے آج مریض کے ساتھ ان کے موجودہ علامات پر طویل گفتگو کی ہے۔ میں نے انھیں بتایا کہ ان کی علامات پٹیلوفیمورل درد سنڈروم کے مطابق ہیں۔ ہم نے علاج کے اختیارات پر تبادلہ خیال کیا اور میں نے تجویز دی ہے کہ ہم اس کے نچلے اعضاء کی طاقت، نقل پذیری کو بڑھانے اور کسی بھی غلط رننگ میکانکس کو درست کرنے کے لیے باضابطہ physical therapy کے ذریعے conservative علاج کے ساتھ شروع کریں۔ میں نے انھیں اب کے لیے دوڑنا آسان کرنے کی ترغیب دی۔ وہ درد کے لیے ibuprofen یا اینٹی انفلامیٹریز لینا جاری رکھ سکتی ہیں۔ تمام سوالات کے جوابات دے دیے گئے۔

ہدایات

مریض جلد ہی مجھ سے فالو اپ کریں گے۔

originalNote:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
 
 Neck pain
 
 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 Jack Torres is a pleasant 40-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of neck pain. The onset of his pain began 1 week ago after he was involved in a motor vehicle accident. He states that he was hit in the back and experienced whiplash. Following the accident he did not present to the emergency room and he does not recall having any swelling or bruising at the neck. He localizes his pain to the posterior aspect of his neck. His pain level is rated at 7 out of 10. When taking ibuprofen he states his pain improves to 5 out of 10. He finds that neck range of motion exacerbates his pain. Initially after the accident he reports that he experienced a couple of headaches, but he states he has not had any recently. He denies any hearing problems or visual disturbances.
 
 SOCIAL HISTORY
 
 Patient reports that he played football years ago without any neck issues.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 Eyes: Denies visual disturbances.
 HENT: Denies hearing loss.
 Musculoskeletal: Reports neck pain.
 Neurological: Denies headaches.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAM
 
 NECK: No swelling noted
 MSK: Examination of the cervical spine: Positive pain to palpation of the soft tissues of the neck. Shoulders and back are nontender to palpation. Positive pain with flexion, rotation, and lateral bending. Severe pain with extension.
 
 RESULTS
 
 3 views of the cervical spine were taken. These reveal no evidence of any fractures or bony abnormalities.
 
 ASSESSMENT
 
 Neck strain.
 
 PLAN
 
 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. We discussed his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture or bony abnormalities. Treatment options were discussed and conservative treatment has been recommended. He will begin taking Motrin 600 mg every 6 to 8 hours. A prescription for Flexeril 10 mg every 12 hours as needed was also provided. He was advised to be mindful of how he moves his neck and to be conservative to avoid straining his neck. I have also recommended that we obtain an MRI for further evaluation as the patient did not go to the emergency room following his accident. He will also be referred to either physical rehab or a chiropractor pending his MRI results.

chatgptNote:
شکایتِ اصلی

گردن میں درد

عارضی مرض کی تاریخ

جیک ٹورس ایک خوش مزاج 40 سالہ مرد ہیں جو آج کلینک میں گردن کے درد کے جائزے کے لیے آئے ہیں۔ ان کے درد کا آغاز ایک ہفتہ قبل موٹر گاڑی کے حادثے کے بعد ہوا۔ انہوں نے بیان کیا کہ ان کی گاڑی کو پیچھے سے ٹکر ماری گئی تھی اور انہیں وھیپلاش (Whiplash) کا تجربہ ہوا۔ حادثے کے بعد وہ ایمرجنسی روم میں نہیں گئے اور انہیں گردن پر سوجن یا چوٹ آنے کی کوئی یاد نہیں ہے۔ وہ اپنے درد کو گردن کے پچھلے حصے میں محسوس کرتے ہیں۔ ان کے درد کی شدت 10 میں سے 7 بتائی گئی ہے۔ جب وہ ایبوپروفین (Ibuprofen) لیتے ہیں تو ان کا درد 10 میں سے 5 تک کم ہو جاتا ہے۔ ان کا کہنا ہے کہ گردن کی حرکت درد کو بڑھا دیتی ہے۔ حادثے کے بعد انہوں نے شروع میں چند سر درد کا تجربہ کیا، لیکن انہوں نے بتایا کہ انہیں حال ہی میں کوئی سر درد نہیں ہوا۔ انہوں نے سماعت میں کوئی مسئلہ یا بصری خرابی سے انکار کیا۔

سماجی تاریخ

مریض نے بتایا کہ انہوں نے برسوں پہلے فٹ بال کھیلا تھا لیکن انہیں گردن سے متعلق کوئی مسئلہ نہیں تھا۔

اعضاء کا جائزہ

آنکھیں: بصری خرابی سے انکار۔
ایچ ای این ٹی (HENT): سماعت کی کمی سے انکار۔
عضلاتی ہڈی کا نظام: گردن کے درد کی رپورٹ۔
اعصابی نظام: سر درد سے انکار۔

جسمانی معائنہ

گردن: کوئی سوجن نہیں دیکھی گئی۔
عضلاتی ہڈی کا نظام: گردنی ریڑھ کی ہڈی کا معائنہ: گردن کے نرم بافتوں کے مس (palpation) سے درد مثبت ہے۔ کندھے اور کمر مس کرنے پر درد نہیں ہے۔ فلیکشن (flexion)، روٹیشن (rotation) اور لیٹرل بینڈنگ (lateral bending) کے ساتھ مثبت درد۔ ایکسٹینشن (extension) کے ساتھ شدید درد۔

نتائج

گردنی ریڑھ کی ہڈی کے 3 ویوز (views) لیے گئے۔ ان سے کوئی فریکچر (fracture) یا ہڈی کی غیر معمولی حالت کا کوئی ثبوت نہیں ملا۔

تشخیص

گردن کا تناؤ (Neck strain)۔

علاج کی منصوبہ بندی

مریض کے معائنے اور ریڈیوگرافک نتائج کا جائزہ لینے کے بعد، میں نے آج مریض کے ساتھ ان کے موجودہ علامات کے بارے میں لمبی گفتگو کی۔ ہم نے ان کے ایکس رے (X-rays) پر فریکچر یا ہڈی کی غیر معمولی حالت کے کوئی نشان نہیں دکھائے جانے پر تبادلہ خیال کیا۔ علاج کے اختیارات پر تبادلہ خیال کیا گیا اور قدامت پسندانہ علاج کی سفارش کی گئی۔ وہ موٹرین (Motrin) 600 ملی گرام ہر 6 سے 8 گھنٹے بعد لینا شروع کریں گے۔ ضرورت کے مطابق فلیکسیرل (Flexeril) 10 ملی گرام ہر 12 گھنٹے بعد لینے کے لیے بھی ایک نسخہ دیا گیا۔ انہیں مشورہ دیا گیا کہ وہ اپنی گردن کی حرکت کا خیال رکھیں اور گردن کو تناؤ سے بچانے کے لیے قدامت پسندانہ انداز اختیار کریں۔ میں نے یہ بھی سفارش کی ہے کہ ہم مریض کے حادثے کے بعد ایمرجنسی روم میں نہ جانے کی وجہ سے مزید تشخیص کے لیے ایم آر آئی (MRI) حاصل کریں۔ ان کے ایم آر آئی کے نتائج کے زیر التوا، انہیں جسمانی بحالی (physical rehab) یا چیراپریکٹر (chiropractor) کے پاس بھیج دیا جائے گا۔

originalNote:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 Brittany Edwards is a 76-year-old female, right-hand-dominant, female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right foot pain. The onset of her pain began 2 days ago, when she was playing tennis and was trying to volley the ball when she got in front of another player and fell on the dorsal aspect of her right foot. She states that she quickly twisted her foot because she was trying to catch herself. The patient reports that she was unable to continue playing secondary to the pain. She states that she wrapped her foot after the game and iced it last night. The patient adds that she kept her foot up on a pillow and took ibuprofen for pain. She denies any numbness. The patient denies any loss of sensation.
 
 The patient has a history of a left leg injury.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 Musculoskeletal: Reports right foot pain.
 Neurological: Denies numbness in the right foot.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAM
 
 SKIN: Warm
 NEURO: Normal sensation.
 MSK:
 Examination of the right foot: Bruising of the plantar and dorsal aspects of the foot. Associated swelling. Tenderness to palpation of the midfoot. Positive piano key test of the 1st and 2nd metatarsals. Warm to touch. Neurovascular intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Strong dorsalis pedis pulse.
 Examination of the left foot: Brisk capillary refill to all digits and light touch intact.
 
 RESULTS
 
 3 views of the right foot were taken. These reveal subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the 2nd metatarsal with a 3 mm separation of the 1st and 2nd metatarsal bases. There is the presence of a bony fragment in the Lisfranc joint space.
 
 ASSESSMENT
 
 Right foot pain, consistent with a Lisfranc fracture.
 
 PLAN
 
 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her x-rays revealed a Lisfranc fracture. We discussed treatment options for this and I have recommended that we proceed with surgical intervention. The plan is to proceed with a right foot ORIF and all indicated procedures. We went over the risk, benefits, and alternatives of the surgery. The risk include but not limited to continued pain, swelling, damage to surrounding tissue including nerves and blood vessels, numbness that could be permanent, infection, nonunion, malunion, failure of hardware, and need for further surgery. There is always a risk of amputation, heart attack, stroke, blood clots, pulmonary embolism, and death. There is a possibility of chronic pain and the inability to get back to the previous level of function. The patient wishes to proceed with the operation and she will follow up with me on the day of surgery. بریٹنی ایڈورڈز، 76 سالہ خاتون، دائیں ہاتھ سے کام کرنے والی، آج کلینک میں دائیں پاؤں کے درد کی تشخیص کے لیے آئی ہیں۔ ان کے درد کی ابتدا 2 دن پہلے ہوئی، جب وہ ٹینس کھیل رہی تھیں اور گیند کو والی کرنے کی کوشش کر رہی تھیں تو وہ ایک اور کھلاڑی کے سامنے گر گئیں اور ان کا پاؤں دائیں پاؤں کے اوپری حصے پر پڑا۔ انہوں نے بتایا کہ انہوں نے خود کو بچانے کی کوشش کرتے ہوئے تیزی سے اپنا پاؤں موڑ لیا۔ مریضہ نے بتایا کہ وہ درد کی وجہ سے کھیل جاری رکھنے میں ناکام رہیں۔ انہوں نے بتایا کہ انہوں نے کھیل کے بعد اپنے پاؤں کو باندھ لیا اور گزشتہ رات اس پر برف لگائی۔ مریضہ نے مزید بتایا کہ انہوں نے اپنا پاؤں تکیے پر رکھا اور درد کے لیے ibuprofen لی۔ انہوں نے کسی بھی سن ہونے سے انکار کیا۔ مریضہ نے کسی بھی حس کے نقصان سے انکار کیا۔

مریضہ کو بائیں پاؤں کی چوٹ کی تاریخ ہے۔

اعضاء کا جائزہ

عضلاتی نظام: دائیں پاؤں کے درد کی شکایت۔
اعصابی نظام: دائیں پاؤں میں سن ہونے سے انکار۔

جسمانی معائنہ

جلد: گرم
اعصاب: معمول کی حس۔
عضلاتی نظام:
دائیں پاؤں کا معائنہ: پاؤں کے پیوند اور اوپری حصے پر خراشیں ہیں۔ اس کے ساتھ سوجن ہے۔ درمیانی پاؤں کے مس کرنے پر درد۔ پہلی اور دوسری میٹاٹارسلس کی مثبت پیانو کی ٹیسٹ۔ چھونے پر گرم۔ دور میں اعصابی نظام سالم۔ کیپیلری ریفل 3 سیکنڈ سے کم ہے۔ ڈورسلس پیڈس کی مضبوط نبض۔
بائیں پاؤں کا معائنہ: تمام انگلیوں میں تیز کیپیلری ریفل اور ہلکی چھونے کی حس سالم۔

نتائج

دائیں پاؤں کی 3 ویوز لی گئیں۔ ان سے دوسرے میٹاٹارسلس کے اڈے کی معمولی ظہری جگہ پُرتشدد اور پہلے اور دوسرے میٹاٹارسلس کے اڈوں کے درمیان 3 ملی میٹر کا فاصلہ ظاہر ہوتا ہے۔ Lisfranc جوڑ کے اندر ہڈی کا ایک ٹکڑا موجود ہے۔

تشخیص

Lisfranc فریکچر کے مطابق دائیں پاؤں کا درد۔

علاج کی منصوبہ بندی

آج مریض کے معائنے اور ریڈیوگرافک نتائج کا جائزہ لینے کے بعد، میں نے مریض کے ساتھ ان کے موجودہ علامات کے بارے میں طویل گفتگو کی ہے۔ میں نے انہیں بتایا کہ ان کے x-rays سے Lisfranc فریکچر کا پتہ چلا ہے۔ ہم نے اس کے علاج کے اختیارات پر تبادلہ خیال کیا اور میں نے تجویز دی کہ ہم سرجیکل مداخلت کے ساتھ آگے بڑھیں۔ منصوبہ دائیں پاؤں ORIF اور تمام اشارے کے طریقہ کار کے ساتھ آگے بڑھنا ہے۔ ہم نے سرجری کے خطرات، فوائد اور متبادل طریقوں پر بات کی۔ خطرات میں شامل ہیں لیکن ان تک محدود نہیں ہیں: مسلسل درد، سوجن، آس پاس کے بافتوں کو نقصان بشمول اعصاب اور خون کی نالیاں، سن جو مستقل ہو سکتی ہے، انفیکشن، غیر ملتحم، malunion، ہارڈ ویئر کی ناکامی، اور مزید سرجری کی ضرورت۔ ہمیشہ amputation، ہارٹ اٹیک، اسٹروک، خون کے جمنے، پلمونری embolism، اور موت کا خطرہ ہوتا ہے۔ دائمی درد اور پچھلی سطح کے فنکشن پر واپس نہ آنے کا امکان ہے۔ مریض آپریشن کے ساتھ آگے بڑھنا چاہتا ہے اور وہ سرجری کے دن مجھ سے فالو اپ کرے گا۔ اس دوران، میں نے مریض کو اپنے دائیں پاؤں کو مضبوط کرنے کے لیے باضابطہ physical therapy میں شامل ہونے کا مشورہ دیا ہے۔

originalNote:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 Kyle Morales is a pleasant 58-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of low back pain.
 
 Onset of his pain began 2 weeks ago, when he was lifting a box of books and felt a pop. The pain is described as aching and sharp. His pain has been increasing since the time of onset and is beginning to radiate down his left leg. The patient denies any pain with sitting. He adds that he has a sedentary job. The patient states that his pain does not affect his job, however he feels that he does not want to be as active as he was previously. He tries to exercise a few times per week, however he is inconsistent. He denies any numbness, tingling, loss of sensation, weakness, and loss of control of his bladder or bowels.
 
 The patient has been taking ibuprofen and Tylenol for pain, which provides some relief. He has not been evaluated for surgery.
 
 SOCIAL HISTORY
 
 He denies smoking. The patient has a history of playing soccer in the midfield position.
 
 FAMILY HISTORY
 
 The patient states that his father has back pain.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 Musculoskeletal: Reports low back pain.
 Neurological: Denies bowl or bladder control issues, numbness, tingling, decreased sensations, or weakness.
 
 VITALS
 
 Blood pressure: 130/70 mm Hg.
 Respiratory rate: 18.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAM
 
 CV: I do not appreciate any murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
 RESPIRATORY: Normal respiratory effort no respiratory distress. Clear to auscultation, bilaterally.
 BACK: No evidence of trauma or deformity
 NEURO: Normal sensation. Patellar and Achilles reflexes are symmetrical.
 MSK: Examination of the lumbar spine: No ecchymosis noted. Midline tenderness at the L4-5 disc space with right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness. Pain with lumbar flexion. Positive supine straight leg test.
 
 RESULTS
 
 The MRI of the lumbar spine was reviewed today. It revealed disc desiccation and a disc bulge with a paracentral disc herniation resulting in moderate right neural foraminal stenosis.
 
 ASSESSMENT
 
 Lumbar back pain at the L4-5 disc space due to a herniated disc with radiculopathy.
 
 PLAN
 
 After reviewing the patient's examination and MRI findings today, I have discussed with the patient that his MRI revealed a herniated disc with radiculopathy. We discussed treatment options for this and I have recommended that we begin with conservative treatment in the form of a corticosteroid injection. With the patient's consent, we will proceed with a corticosteroid injection into the lumbar spine today. The patient was made aware of the risks of bleeding, infection, nerve damage, blood vessel damage, reaction to the medication, including skin changes, swelling, and also, the risk of elevated glucose levels if the patient were diabetic.

chatgptNote:
تاریخِ مرضِ حال حاضر

کائل مورالیس ایک خوش مزاج 58 سالہ مرد ہیں جو آج کمر درد کی تشخیص کے لیے کلینک میں آئے ہیں۔

ان کے درد کی ابتدا 2 ہفتے پہلے ہوئی، جب وہ کتابوں کا ایک ڈبہ اٹھا رہے تھے اور انہیں ایک "پاپ" کی آواز آئی۔ درد کو دردِ عضلات اور تیز بتایا گیا ہے۔ ان کے درد میں ابتداء کے بعد سے اضافہ ہو رہا ہے اور یہ ان کے بائیں پاؤں میں پھیلنا شروع ہو گیا ہے۔ مریض بیٹھنے پر کسی قسم کے درد کی نفی کرتے ہیں۔ وہ مزید کہتے ہیں کہ ان کی ملازمت کارِ بیٹھنے والی ہے۔ مریض کہتے ہیں کہ ان کے درد سے ان کی ملازمت متاثر نہیں ہوتی، تاہم انہیں لگتا ہے کہ وہ پہلے جتنے فعال تھے، اتنے فعال نہیں رہنا چاہتے۔ وہ ہفتے میں چند بار ورزش کرنے کی کوشش کرتے ہیں، تاہم وہ مستقل نہیں ہیں۔ وہ کسی قسم کی سنّی، جھنجھناہٹ، احساس کا فقدان، کمزوری، اور مثانے یا آنتوں کے کنٹرول کے فقدان کی نفی کرتے ہیں۔

مریض درد کے لیے ایبوپروفین اور ٹائلینول لے رہے ہیں، جس سے کچھ راحت ملتی ہے۔ ان کی سرجری کے لیے کوئی تشخیص نہیں کی گئی۔

سماجی تاریخ

وہ سگریٹ نوشی سے انکار کرتے ہیں۔ مریض کی تاریخ میں مڈفیلڈ پوزیشن میں فٹ بال کھیلنے کی ہے۔

خاندانی تاریخ

مریض کہتے ہیں کہ ان کے والد کو کمر درد ہے۔

اعضاء کا جائزہ

عضلاتی ہڈیوں کا نظام: کمر کے نچلے حصے میں درد کی رپورٹ۔
اعصابی نظام: آنتوں یا مثانے کے کنٹرول کے مسائل، سنّی، جھنجھناہٹ، احساس میں کمی، یا کمزوری کی نفی۔

حیاتیات

بلڈ پریشر: 130/70 ملی میٹر Hg۔
سانس کی رفتار: 18۔

جسمانی معائنہ

قلبی نظام: مجھے کوئی گڑگڑاہٹ، رگڑ، یا تیز رفتار نہیں لگ رہا ہے۔
سانس لینے کا نظام: معمول کی سانس لینے کی کوشش، کوئی سانس لینے میں دشواری نہیں۔ دونوں طرف سے سماعت پر صاف۔
کمر: کوئی صدمہ یا بدصورتی کا ثبوت نہیں۔
اعصابی نظام: معمول کی حس۔ پیٹیلا اور اخیلز ریفلیکس متناسب ہیں۔
عضلاتی ہڈیوں کا نظام: کمری ریڑھ کی ہڈی کا معائنہ: کوئی چوٹ نہیں دیکھی گئی۔ L4-5 ڈسک کی جگہ پر درمیانی لکیر کی حساسیت کے ساتھ دائیں جانب کمری پیریورٹبرل حساسیت۔ کمری فلیکشن کے ساتھ درد۔ مثبت supine straight leg test۔

نتائج

کمری ریڑھ کی ہڈی کا ایم آر آئی آج جائزہ لیا گیا۔ اس سے ڈسک کی خشک ہونے اور ایک ڈسک bulge کا پتہ چلا جس کے نتیجے میں دائیں جانب اعصابی foraminal stenosis کی اعتدال کی شدت ہوئی۔

تشخیص

ہیرنیٹڈ ڈسک کے باعث L4-5 ڈسک کی جگہ پر کمری کمر درد اور radiculopathy۔

منصوبہ

مریض کے معائنے اور ایم آر آئی کے نتائج کا جائزہ لینے کے بعد، میں نے مریض سے بات کی کہ ان کے ایم آر آئی سے ہیرنیٹڈ ڈسک اور radiculopathy کا پتہ چلا ہے۔ ہم نے اس کے لیے علاج کے اختیارات پر تبادلہ خیال کیا اور میں نے تجویز دی کہ ہم کورٹیکوسٹیرائڈ انجیکشن کی شکل میں قدامت پسندانہ علاج کے ساتھ شروع کریں۔ مریض کی رضامندی سے، ہم آج کمری ریڑھ کی ہڈی میں کورٹیکوسٹیرائڈ انجیکشن کے ساتھ آگے بڑھیں گے۔ مریض کو خون بہنے، انفیکشن، اعصاب کو نقصان، خون کی نالیوں کو نقصان، دوا پر ردعمل، بشمول جلد میں تبدیلی، سوجن، اور اگر مریض ذیابیطس کا شکار ہے تو بلڈ شوگر کے بڑھنے کے خطرات سے آگاہ کیا گیا۔

originalNote:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist injury.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana Scott is a pleasant 61-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a right wrist injury. The patient sustained this injury yesterday morning, 05/12/2022, when she slipped on the stairs while carrying a laundry basket. She states she tried to catch herself with her arms outstretched. The patient reports an immediate onset of pain and swelling in her right wrist. She denies any previous injuries to her right arm. The patient rates her pain level as a 9/10. Her pain is aggravated by movement. The patient also reports numbness and tingling in her fingers. She has been icing and wrapping her right wrist with an ACE wrap. The patient has also been taking ibuprofen, which provides some relief. She notes fully extending her arm while resting it on a pillow alleviates some of her pain as well.

The patient is going on vacation in 1 month.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Reports numbness and tingling to the digits of the right hand.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: Elevated at 140/70 mmHg.
Heart Rate: 80 beats per minute.
Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths per minute.
Body Temperature: 97.2 degrees F.
HEAD: Normocephalic
NECK: No swelling noted
CV: No bilateral lower extremity edema. No carotid bruit. No murmurs, gallops or rubs heard during auscultation of the heart. Palpabale pulses to the bilateral lower extremities.
RESPIRATORY: Normal respiratory effort no respiratory distress. Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
GI/GU: Non-distended
BACK: No evidence of trauma or deformity
NECK: No adenopathy. No thyromegaly.
MSK: Examination of the right wrist: Limited range of movement. Tenderness to palpation. Pain on flexion and extension. Pain with radial deviation and lateral deviation. Pain with wrist abduction and adduction. The metacarpals are intact. Obvious swelling and bruising. Tenderness on palpation throughout. There is evidence of potential fracture feeling and bony crepitus.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right wrist were taken today. These reveal the fracture appears extra-articular and proximal to the radioulnar joint. Dorsal angulation of the distal fracture fragment is present to a variable degree. Dorsal angulation is severe, presenting with a dinner fork deformity. An ulnar styloid fracture is present.

ASSESSMENT

Right wrist Colles fracture.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have discussed with the patient that her x-rays revealed a right wrist Colles fracture. We discussed treatment options and I have recommended that we proceed with a right wrist ORIF and all indicated procedures. We reviewed the risks, benefits, and alternatives of the surgery. I explained that we should schedule the operation for as soon as possible to ensure adequate healing and to limit malformation of the wrist. I advised that this procedure will require her to be admitted to the hospital for an overnight stay.

In the meantime, the patient will be placed in a thumb spica brace and receive instructions on its proper usage. I have prescribed the patient Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours to treat her pain. We also discussed that her postoperative course will include wearing a brace for 6 weeks. A few weeks after surgery, the patient will initiate formal physical therapy and will attend 3 times per week to strengthen her right wrist. The patient has a 2-week vacation planned in 1 month. I recommended that we consult with her physical therapist to determine if there are exercises she can perform on her own instead of postponing her vacation.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 4 weeks status post surgery to discuss her progress.

chatgptNote:
شکایتِ اصلی

دائیں کلائی کی چوٹ۔

عارضی مرض کی تاریخ

ڈائانا سکاٹ 61 سالہ خوش مزاج خاتون ہیں جو آج کلائی کی چوٹ کے جائزے کے لیے کلینک میں آئی ہیں۔ مریضہ نے یہ چوٹ کل صبح، 12 مئی 2022 کو سیڑھیوں سے پھسل کر لگائی جب وہ لانڈری باسکٹ لے کر جا رہی تھیں۔ انہوں نے بتایا کہ انہوں نے اپنے ہاتھوں کو پھیلا کر خود کو بچانے کی کوشش کی۔ مریضہ کو دائیں کلائی میں درد اور سوجن کا فوری آغاز محسوس ہوا۔ انہوں نے اپنے دائیں بازو کو پہلے کبھی چوٹ نہیں لگائی۔ مریضہ اپنے درد کی سطح کو 10 میں سے 9 بتاتی ہے۔ حرکت سے ان کا درد بڑھ جاتا ہے۔ مریضہ اپنی انگلیوں میں سن numbness اور tingling کی بھی شکایت کرتی ہے۔ انہوں نے اپنی دائیں کلائی پر برف لگائی ہے اور اسے ACE wrap سے باندھ رکھا ہے۔ مریضہ نے ibuprofen بھی لی ہے، جس سے کچھ راحت ملی ہے۔ انہوں نے نوٹ کیا کہ تکیے پر بازو کو آرام دیتے ہوئے اسے مکمل طور پر پھیلانے سے ان کے درد میں کچھ کمی آتی ہے۔

مریضہ ایک ماہ میں چھٹی پر جانے والی ہیں۔

جسمانی جائزہ

عضلاتی ہڈی: دائیں کلائی میں درد اور سوجن کی شکایت۔
اعصابی: دائیں ہاتھ کی انگلیوں میں numbness اور tingling کی شکایت۔

حیاتیات

بلڈ پریشر: 140/70 mmHg پر بلند۔
قلب کی رفتار: فی منٹ 80 دھڑکن۔
سانس کی رفتار: فی منٹ 20 سانسیں۔
جسم کا درجہ حرارت: 97.2 ڈگری فارنہیٹ۔
سر: Normocephalic
گردن: کوئی سوجن نہیں دیکھی گئی۔
قلبی نظام: کوئی دو طرفہ زیریں اعضاء کی edema نہیں ۔ کوئی carotid bruit نہیں ۔ دل کی auscultation کے دوران کوئی murmurs، gallops یا rubs نہیں سنا گیا۔ دونوں زیریں اعضاء میں محسوس ہونے والی نبض۔
سانس لینے کا عمل: معمول کا سانس لینے کا عمل، کوئی سانس کی تکلیف نہیں۔ پھیپھڑے دونوں طرف auscultation کے لیے صاف۔
پیٹ/پیشاب کی نالی: غیر پھیلا ہوا
پیٹھ: کوئی صدمہ یا deformities کا ثبوت نہیں
گردن: کوئی adenopathy نہیں ۔ کوئی thyromegaly نہیں ۔
عضلاتی ہڈی: دائیں کلائی کا معائنہ: محدود range of movement۔ palpation پر tenderness۔ flexion اور extension پر درد۔ radial deviation اور lateral deviation پر درد۔ کلائی کے abduction اور adduction پر درد۔ metacarpals سالم ہیں۔ واضح سوجن اور کبود۔ پورے حصے میں palpation پر tenderness۔ ممکنہ fracture محسوس ہونے اور bony crepitus کا ثبوت موجود ہے۔

نتائج

آج دائیں کلائی کی X-rays لی گئیں۔ ان سے پتہ چلتا ہے کہ fracture extra-articular ہے اور radioulnar joint کے قریب ہے۔ distal fracture fragment کا dorsal angulation مختلف مقدار میں موجود ہے۔ dorsal angulation شدید ہے، جو dinner fork deformity کے ساتھ پیش ہو رہا ہے۔ ulnar styloid fracture موجود ہے۔

تشخیص

دائیں کلائی Colles fracture۔

یोजना

آج مریض کے معائنے اور radiographic نتائج کا جائزہ لینے کے بعد، میں نے مریض سے بات کی کہ ان کی X-rays سے دائیں کلائی Colles fracture کا پتہ چلا ہے۔ ہم نے علاج کے اختیارات پر تبادلہ خیال کیا اور میں نے تجویز دی کہ ہم دائیں کلائی ORIF اور تمام اشارے کے طریقہ کار کے ساتھ آگے بڑھیں۔ ہم نے سرجری کے خطرات، فوائد اور متبادل طریقوں کا جائزہ لیا۔ میں نے وضاحت کی کہ ہمیں کلائی کی مناسب healing اور deformities کو محدود کرنے کے لیے جلد از جلد آپریشن کا شیڈول کرنا چاہیے۔ میں نے مشورہ دیا کہ اس طریقہ کار کے لیے انہیں رات بھر کے لیے ہسپتال میں داخل ہونے کی ضرورت ہوگی۔

دریں اثنا، مریض کو thumb spica brace لگایا جائے گا اور اس کے مناسب استعمال کے بارے میں ہدایات دی جائیں گی۔ میں نے مریض کو درد کے علاج کے لیے Ultram 50 mg ہر 6 گھنٹے بعد تجویز کی ہے۔ ہم نے یہ بھی تبادلہ خیال کیا کہ ان کے postoperative عمل میں 6 ہفتوں تک brace پہننا شامل ہوگا۔ سرجری کے چند ہفتوں بعد، مریض باقاعدہ physical therapy شروع کریں گے اور اپنی دائیں کلائی کو مضبوط کرنے کے لیے ہفتے میں 3 بار حاضر ہوں گے۔ مریض نے ایک ماہ میں 2 ہفتوں کی چھٹیوں کی منصوبہ بندی کی ہے۔ میں نے تجویز دی کہ ہم ان کے

CHIEF COMPLAINT
 
 Right ankle injury.
 
 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 Jacqueline Price is a pleasant 28-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a right ankle injury. The patient sustained the injury when she fell while in mountain biking lessons. She states that her ankle twisted outward. The patient localizes the pain to her lateral aspect of her right ankle. She denies any tingling, but notes numbness in her toes. She notes that she is able to move her ankle a little bit. The patient states that she has difficulty walking. Additionally, she notes that she has a limp when she ambulates. She has taken Tylenol for the pain, but states that it was not beneficial. She denies hearing a pop, but did hear a crack when the injury happened. Ms. Price notes that she has had a fever.
 
 SOCIAL HISTORY
 
 The patient has been mountain biking for 3 years.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 Constitutional: Reports fever.
 Musculoskeletal: Reports right ankle pain.
 Neurological: Reports numbness in the right ankle.
 
 VITALS
 
 Temperature in offce today was 98.6.
 BP: 118/77.
 HR: 77 bpm.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAM
 
 CV: Mild edema.
 MSK: Examination of the right ankle there is edema and erythema on the lateral malleolus on the right side. There is associated ecchymosis and a few excoriations. Pain with palpation of the right lateral malleolus. Decreased flexion and extension of the right ankle, as well as internal and external rotation. There is no apparent injury to the right knee or foot.
 
 RESULTS
 
 X-ray of the right foot taken in office today reveals no acute fracture or bony abnormalities.
 
 ASSESSMENT
 
 Acute right ankle sprain.
 
 PLAN
 
 We reviewed the patient's x-rays in detail today. The plan is to place the patient in an Aircast and provide the patient with crutches. I have also prescribed the patient meloxicam 15 mg to treat the pain. I have advised her to ice the area for 20 minutes 5 times per day. She can weight-bear as tolerated. I anticipate that she will improve in the next 2 weeks. If her pain does not improve with the Aircast, I will recommend formal physical therapy or pursuing further imaging.

 Joint pain
 
 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 Ms. Thompson is a 27 y.o. female with a history of carpal tunnel release done a couple years ago, chronic back pain, and depression. She presents today for joint pain.
 
 Ms. Thompson reports that over the course of the month she has begun swimming more regularly and trying to be more active. She has experienced bad right knee pain. The patient reports that her knee starts hurting after a couple of laps. She notes previously she could swim 10 laps. She denies injury or trauma to the knee.
 
 The patient has a history of chronic back pain that has been intermittent, but right now it has been doing well. She denies pain radiating down her legs.
 
 The patient has a history of depression, which has been going really well with medication and therapy. She is trying to get outside more and it has been helping her with her depression. She notes she is sleeping and eating well. She denies concerns about hurting herself or others.
 
 The patient's carpal tunnel is doing really well. She has been getting full range of motion and it has felt a lot better.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Endorses right knee joint pain. Endorses chronic back pain.
 â€¢ Psychiatric: Endorses depression.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
 
 â€¢ Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect. Grips are equal bilaterally.
 â€¢ Neck: Supple without thyromegaly or cervical lymphadenopathy.
 â€¢ Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
 â€¢ Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema. Pain with patellar inhibition. Pain with range of motion of the right knee.
 
 RESULTS
 
 X-ray of the right knee is unremarkable.
 
 ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
 
 Ms. Thompson is a 27 y.o. female who presents today for evaluation of right knee pain.
 
 Chondromalacia of right patella.

Regarding his depression, he reports that he has been consistent with his Prozac and has not had any incidents in a while.

His hypertension has been slightly uncontrolled. He reports that he is taking his blood pressure at home and it is running high. The patient states that he is pretty regular with his Norvasc during the business week, but on the weekends he will forget to bring it with him.

He reports that he had a prior lobectomy a couple of years ago. He endorses shortness of breath with exertion. The patient has difficulty breathing due to allergies and the heat in the summertime. He also endorses some nasal congestion from the pollen. He reports that he runs in the morning. Occasionally, if it is relatively humid, he will struggle a little bit with breathing and he will feel a little bit of a pounding in his chest. He states that it usually goes away. He reports that he runs 4 to 5 miles a day.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

â€¢ Cardiovascular: Endorses intermittent palpitations. Endorses dyspnea on exertion.
â€¢ Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath. Endorses cough.

â€¢ Blood Pressure: 124/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Initially, the pain was intermittent, but over the last 48 hours it has been constant. He has taken Tylenol, but it does not seem to help. He thinks he has hematuria, but it is hard to detect but it does look a little off color. He endorses nausea and vomiting if he exerts himself or climbs the stairs to his apartment or runs to catch the bus. He also endorses dizziness and lightheadedness with pain in his abdomen.

 Regarding his gastroesophageal reflux, he reports that he has been doing well with his diet, but notes lately with his pain, he has been eating more fast food and takeout since these options come with delivery. He is staying hydrated. He is taking Protonix 40 mg daily as directed.

 Kidney stones.

 Migraines.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Upper respiratory infection.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan Harris is a 57-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery bypass grafting, hyperlipidemia, and OCD, who presents with an upper respiratory infection.

The patient reports that about a week ago he started to get a cold, which has worsened in the last 2 or 3 days. He endorses some postnasal drip for the beginning of the week, however, it has seemed to move into his chest. He denies chest pain other than his chest congestion. He was able to exercise prior to getting sick. He denies anyone else being sick in his house. He denies fever and shortness of breath.

Regarding his high cholesterol, he states he has been pretty good for the most part. He did a little travel over the last week or so and his diet was not great but for the most part it is pretty good. He is on Crestor 20 mg a day and is tolerating it well. He denies any muscle aches. He had his bypass grafting last year and is doing great.

The patient is fully vaccinated for COVID-19.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

â€¢ Constitutional: Denies fevers.
â€¢ Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses post nasal drip.
â€¢ Cardiovascular: Endorses chest congestion.
â€¢ Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
â€¢ Psychiatric: Endorses obsessive compulsive disorder.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

â€¢ Neck: Positive cervical lymphadenopathy
â€¢ Respiratory: Rhonchi and wheezing bilaterally.

VITALS REVIEWED

â€¢ Oxygen Saturation: 96%.

RESULTS

Lipid panel: Within normal limits.

COVID-19 test: Positive

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan Harris is a 57-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery bypass grafting, hyperlipidemia, and OCD who presents today for upper respiratory symptoms.

COVID-19 Positive.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with upper respiratory symptoms and his COVID-19 test was positive today. He has received both doses of the vaccination. His symptoms seem to be very mild at this time. His oxygenation is good at 96%.
â€¢ Patient Education and Counseling: I advised him to quarantine for 10 days and we discussed that he should try to avoid family members. I asked him to call me if his symptoms worsen.

Hypercholesterolemia.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: He is doing well on Crestor 20 mg once a day. His cholesterol looked good on his most recent lipid panel.
â€¢ Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged him to continue to watch his diet.
â€¢ Additional Testing: We will go ahead and order another lipid panel for 6 months.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: He can continue Crestor 20 mg once a day.

History of coronary artery bypass grafting.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting approximately 1 year ago. His coronary artery disease seems to be under control currently. He denies chest pain.
â€¢ Additional Testing: We will do a stress test in 6 months.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

She states her high blood pressure has been stable with lisinopril. The patient has a cuff at home to measure her blood pressure herself.

Regarding her knee, she had an ACL repair on her right knee about 5 years ago and everything has been going well. She has not had any issues with mobility.

She denies chest pain, shortness of breath, vomiting, diarrhea, headaches, and abdominal pain. She denies any difficulty urinating or burning when she urinates.

â€¢ Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
â€¢ Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Evelyn Morris is a 56-year-old female with a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease, prior carpal tunnel release, and a herniated disc. She presents for her annual exam.

The patient states she has been doing okay with her herniated disc in her back. She has not had any back pain or any limitations in movement. She had a steroid injection for her herniated disc several months ago, which has been doing well.

Her right carpal tunnel release was performed a couple of years ago and she is back to work. She has full range of motion and it feels really good. No numbness or tingling in her hands.

She has had prior stenting for her heart and heart vessels in the past. Over the last month, she reports chest pain approximately 3-4 times a week with ambulation. Her chest pain does resolve with rest. The pain is described as burning and is located in the middle of her chest. She denies pain at rest.

She has had a little bit of nasal congestion from allergies. The patient denies, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, or lower extremity edema.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

â€¢ Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills.
â€¢ Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion form allergies.
â€¢ Cardiovascular: Denies dyspnea. Endorses chest pain with exertion.
â€¢ Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Denies muscle pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

â€¢ Neck: No carotid bruits appreciable.
â€¢ Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
â€¢ Cardiovascular: Slight 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
â€¢ Integumentary: Well-healed surgical scars on her right wrist.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram shows reduced ejection fraction at 45% with a slight mitral regurgitation.

ECG prior coronary artery disease. No new changes.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Evelyn Morris is a 56-year-old female with a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease, prior carpal tunnel release, and a herniated disc. She presents for her annual exam.

Status post right carpal tunnel release.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well postoperatively. She has returned to work and denies any recurrent symptoms.

Herniated disc.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: She has been asymptomatic since receiving a steroid injection several months ago. I do not think we need to refer her for any further steroid injections or physical therapy at this time.
â€¢ Patient Education and Counseling: If she has any recurrent symptoms, she will let me know and we can take it from there.

Coronary artery disease.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: She reports a burning chest pain with exertion approximately 3 times per week for the past month. Her recent echocardiogram demonstrated a reduced ejection fraction of 45%.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: Continue aspirin and Toprol. Initiate Crestor 20 mg once daily.
â€¢ Additional Testing: We will order a cardiac stress test and a lipid panel for further evaluation.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

originalNote:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up to an abnormal labs.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Joyce Price is a 50-year-old female with a past medical history significant for COPD, congestive heart failure who presents for follow-up to an abnormal lab finding.

The patient reports that she has been feeling really tired lately. She reports that over the past couple of months, her energy has really gone down. She used to be really active, trying to be as healthy as she can be with running and climbing, at least an hour or two a day. Over the past month, her activity has slowly decreased. She reports that, due to her fatigue, she has not been able to keep up with her exercise. She reports that she had noticed a little weight loss, but she believes that was due to her doing really well with her exercises.

The patient reports that her COPD is doing well. She reports that she has not been smoking since she quit. She reports that during the changes of the season, it gets a little harder for her to breathe, but she believes that is because of her allergies.

From a congestive heart failure standpoint, she reports that she has been doing really well with her diet. She reports that she has been staying away from French fries and all the other salty foods that she likes to eat. She denies any swelling in her legs.

She reports that she has a good support system with her boyfriend and her brother.

She reports that she has not noticed any blood in her stool at this time. She denies that her stools are dark or black in color. She denies that she has had any abnormal bleeding between menses. The patient denies any other symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, fever, chills, or malaise.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

â€¢ Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills. Endorses weight loss. Endorses fatigue.
â€¢ Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea.
â€¢ Respiratory: Â  Endorses shortness of breath with seasonal changes.
â€¢ Gastrointestinal: Denies hematochezia, melena.
â€¢ Genitourinary: Denies abnormal bleeding between menses.
â€¢ Neurological: Positive for dizziness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

â€¢ Neck: Supple without cervical lymphadenopathy.
â€¢ Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
â€¢ Cardiovascular: Regular rate. Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. No gallops or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
â€¢ Gastrointestinal: Tenderness to palpation to the right lower quadrant.

RESULTS

Hemoglobin A1c is 8.2.
Labs are within normal limits.
Anemia labs: Still pending.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Joyce Price is a 50-year-old female with a past medical history significant for COPD, congestive heart failure, who presents for follow up of abnormal labs.

1. Abnormal labs.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: Her recent hemoglobin level was low at 8.2. Her available anemia labs were normal, but we need to wait for her pending labs for a definitive anemia diagnosis.
â€¢ Additional Testing: I would like to obtain an endoscopy and colonoscopy to evaluate for gastrointestinal bleeding.
â€¢ Specialist Referrals: We will put in a referral to gastroenterology to perform her endoscopy and colonoscopy.

2. COPD.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well. She ceased tobacco use several years ago and continues to abstain from this.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: I do not think she needs any inhalers at this time. She should continue to stay away from smoking.

3. Congestive heart failure.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: She is doing well and continues to follow dietary modifications, particularly with limiting her sodium intake.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: Continue on Toprol and lisinopril, as well as her current dose of Lasix 20 mg a day.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT
 
 Back pain.
 
 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 Bryan Smith is a 55-year-old male with a past medical history significant for and prior discectomy, who presents with back pain.
 
 The patient reports he felt something in the lower right side of his back while pushing a refrigerator up through another room. This happened about 5 days ago. The patient experiences pain while bending over. He has a history of a discectomy. He is worried that something happened. He has been taking ibuprofen, which has not been beneficial alone. With the combination of Tylenol and ibuprofen, he experiences symptomatic relief. He denies numbness and tingling in his legs, and any problems with his bladder or bowels.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 â€¢ Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
 â€¢ Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
 â€¢ Gastrointestinal: Denies hematemesis, hematochezia, melena, heartburn, or abdominal pain.
 â€¢ Genitourinary: Denies urinary urgency, pain, or incontinence.
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower right side back pain.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
 
 â€¢ Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
 â€¢ Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation to the right lumbar spine and the paraspinal muscles. Decreased flexion and extension of the back. Positive straight leg raise on the right. Strength is good bilaterally in the lower extremities.
 
 RESULTS
 
 X-ray of the lumbar spine is unremarkable. Normal bony alignment. No fractures were noted.
 
 Labs: Within normal limits.
 
 ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
 
 Bryan Smith is a 55-year-old male with a past medical history significant for prior discectomy, who presents with back pain.
 
 Lumbar strain.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: He reports right-sided low back after moving a refrigerator approximately 5 days ago. X-ray of his lumbar spine is unremarkable. I do not believe this is related to his previous discectomy.
 â€¢ Additional Testing: We will order a MRI of the lumbar spine for further evaluation.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily, as well as Ultram 50 mg every 4 hours as needed.
 â€¢ Specialist Referrals: We will refer him to physical therapy to be started after we get his MRI results back.
 â€¢ Patient Education and Counseling: I advised the patient to discontinue the use of ibuprofen, but he may continue using Tylenol if he wishes.
 
 Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT
 
 Follow-up of chronic problems.
 
 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 Edward Butler is a 59-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior rotator cuff repair. He presents for a follow-up of his chronic problems.

originalNote:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
 
 Abnormal labs.
 
 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 John Brooks is a 55-year-old male with a past medical history significant for anxiety and epilepsy, who presents with an abnormal lab finding.
 
 The patient was notified by the emergency room physician that he had elevated blood sugar levels. He was started on metformin 500 mg twice daily during that time. He notes that he has going from place to place for different events and they've recently had a lot of visitors; therefore, he was not monitoring his sugar intake over the last few weeks.
 
 In terms of his anxiety, he states he has had his moments, but now that it is almost the weekend, his symptoms have improved.
 
 Regarding his epilepsy, he has not had any seizures in a few months. He continues to take Keppra.
 
 The patient denies chest pain, shortness of breath, vomiting, dizziness, fevers, and chills.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 â€¢ Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills.
 â€¢ Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea.
 â€¢ Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
 â€¢ Neurological: Endorses epilepsy.
 â€¢ Psychiatric: Endorses anxiety.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
 
 â€¢ Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
 â€¢ Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm.
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Trace pitting edema to the bilateral lower extremities.
 
 RESULTS
 
 Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.
 
 Non-fasting glucose is elevated.
 
 ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
 
 John Brooks is a 55-year-old male with a past medical history significant for anxiety and epilepsy. He presents today with an abnormal lab finding.
 
 Newly diagnosed diabetes.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: His past hemoglobin A1c levels have been borderline high, but his most recent level was 8. His blood glucose level is also elevated in clinic today.
 â€¢ Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 500 mg twice daily.
 
 Epilepsy.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: He saw his neurologist about 3 months ago and has been asymptomatic for the past few months.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: Continue Keppra at current dosage.
 
 Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

originalNote:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
 
 Shortness of breath.
 
 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 Lawrence Walker is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for type 1 diabetes, congestive heart failure, depression, and reflux, who presents with complaints of shortness of breath.
 
 The patient states he has had some shortness of breath and mild leg swelling which he thinks has to do with eating some salty foods at some house parties recently. His shortness of breath is primarily with exertion such as walking up the stairs. This has been going on for about 10 days now. He woke from sleep once with shortness of breath about a week ago. He also notes discomfort lying flat in bed and musculoskeletal stiffness in the morning. He states that it takes him a little while to get up.
 
 Regarding his type 1 diabetes, he is using his insulin pump. He has been consistently monitoring his blood sugars during the working week, but notes that he checks less on the weekends, due to being busy. He is trying to avoid sugar but admits to an affinity for chocolate bars.
 
 Regarding his depression, he states that it has been a crazy year and a half. He has tried some natural solutions. In the summer, he did daily outdoor stretching, which was great; but now that the weather has changed, he needs to find some alternatives. He is not ready to try any medications. He denies suicidal and homicidal ideation.
 
 Regarding his GERD, he is taking his omeprazole. He has made some lifestyle modifications like cutting back on his red bull intake and other caffeine. Reducing his alcohol intake has been tough during the holiday season, but he is getting better about this.
 
 The patient denies chest pain, fever, chills, cough, and abdominal pain.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 â€¢ Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills.Â Endorses fatigue.
 â€¢ Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain. Endorses dyspnea on exertion.
 â€¢ Respiratory: Denies coughor wheezing. Endorses shortness of breath..
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower extremity edema.
 â€¢ Psychiatric: Endorses depression.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
 
 â€¢ Neck: No carotid bruits appreciable. No jugular venous distention.
 â€¢ Respiratory: Rales are heard bilaterally at lung bases.
 â€¢ Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: 1+ pitting bilateral lower extremity edema.
 
 RESULTS
 
 Chest x-ray did not show any evidence of airspace disease.
 
 Labs were all within normal limits, including the WBC.
 
 ASSESSMENT
 
 Lawrence Walker is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for type 1 diabetes, congestive heart failure, depression, and reflux, who presents with complaints of shortness of breath.
 
 PLAN
 
 Acute heart failure exacerbation.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: The patient is retaining fluid. He has noticed increased fluid retention following dietary indiscretion. He has experienced dyspnea on exertion for the past 10 days.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: Initiate Lasix 40 mg a day.
 â€¢ Patient Education and Counseling: I advised the patient to monitor and log his daily weights. He will contact me if these continue to increase. He was instructed to call me or 911 if he experiences dyspnea at rest.
 
 Type 1 diabetes.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: This is currently stable with use of an insulin pump.
 â€¢ Additional Testing: I will order a hemoglobin A1c in 1 month.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: He will continue the insulin pump. The patient will follow up with his endocrinologist.
 â€¢ Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to have an eye exam.
 
 Depression.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: The patient has been doing well with outdoor stretching. He continues to decline the use of medications for this issue.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: I will refer him to psychiatry as his current management strategy is unsustainable due to the change in season.
 â€¢ Patient Education and Counseling: We will defer initiating medication at this time.
 
 Acid reflux.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: His symptoms are stable with medication.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: Continue omeprazole 20 mg a day.
 
 Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. his endo

originalNote:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Bruce Howard is a 60-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type 2 diabetes, and hypertension who presents for follow up of his chronic problems.

In regards to his depression, the patient notes that it has been a crazy year and a half. He experienced a lot of anxiety while getting ready for Thanksgiving but it is starting to resolve now. He denies suicidal and homicidal ideation. The patient and his wife began going on walks and gardening over the summer and he notes good relief of his depression from this; however, the season has changed and he needs an alterative method of management. He has preferred to avoid medications in the past.

The patient is still taking metformin for his diabetes. He notes some dietary indiscretion with Thanksgiving but he is doing better with this now.

In terms of his hypertension, he notes he is compliant with lisinopril. He did buy a blood pressure cuff and is checking his blood pressure at home. His blood pressures have reportedly been good.

He denies chest pain, dyspnea, abdominal pain, hematochezia, or weight loss.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

â€¢ Constitutional: Denies weight loss.
â€¢ Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
â€¢ Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
â€¢ Gastrointestinal: Denies hematochezia or abdominal pain.
â€¢ Psychiatric: Endorses anxiety and depression.â€¯ Denies suicidal and homicidal ideations.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

â€¢ Constitutional: Well-developed, well-nourished, in no apparent distress.
â€¢ Neck: No carotid bruits appreciable.
â€¢ Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
â€¢ Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur heard at the left base, heard previously.
â€¢ Musculoskeletal: 1+ nonpitting edema bilaterally.

RESULTS

EKG was unremarkable.

Diabetic labs revealed an elevated hemoglobin A1c of 8.

ASSESSMENT

Bruce Howard is a 60-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type 2 diabetes, and hypertension who presents for follow up of his chronic problems.

PLAN

Depression.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: He has been doing well with going on morning walks; however, this has ended due to the cooler weather. He continues to decline the use of medications for this issue.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: We will defer initiating medication at this time.
â€¢ Specialist Referrals: I will refer him to psychiatry to engage in talk therapy.

Diabetes type 2.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: The patient admits to recent dietary indiscretion. His most recent hemoglobin A1c was elevated at 8 percent. He is compliant with metformin.
â€¢ Additional Testing: I will order a repeat hemoglobin A1c in the next couple of months. I will also order a lipid panel.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: We will increase his metformin to 1000 mg twice a day.

Hypertension.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: He has been monitoring his blood pressure on a regular basis. Blood pressure is well controlled at this time. He has a systolic ejection murmur that continues to be heard on exam.
â€¢ Additional Testing: I will order an echocardiogram to reassess the heart murmur.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: He will continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

 Chest pain and hypertension.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Alan Butler is a 61-year-old male presenting with complaints of shortness of breath.

The patient states that over the weekend, he took a very long bike ride for approximately 3 hours, and when he returned, he was very lightheaded and short of breath. He notes that it was difficult to catch his breath afterward. He endorses that he had mild chest pain at that time, however, it eventually went away after about an hour. He denies any fever at this time or any other symptoms at this time. No other members in his family have been sick.

The patient is currently taking Imitrex as needed for his migraines. His migraines are under control and he avoids exposure to bright lights.

The patient is currently taking Protonix for his reflux and he is doing well with this.

The patient had cataract surgery about 4.5 months ago. He notes that his vision is okay since then.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

â€¢ Constitutional: No fevers.
â€¢ Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and dyspnea on exertion.
â€¢ Respiratory: Endorses a cough. Endorses shortness of breath.
â€¢ Gastrointestinal: Endorses reflux.
â€¢ Neurological: Endorses migraines. Endorses lightheadedness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

â€¢ Neck: Supple.Â  No jugular venous distension.
â€¢ Respiratory: Slight expiratory wheezing bilaterally.
â€¢ Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.
â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Trace edema in the bilateral lower extremities.

RESULTS

Pulmonary function test are within normal limits.

X-ray of the chest is unremarkable.

CBC: Within normal limits.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 61-year-old male who presents for shortness of breath.

Shortness of breath.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: I reviewed the patient's chest x-ray, pulmonary function test, and labs which were all normal. He does have slight expiratory wheezing bilaterally on exam. I suspect his episode of shortness of breath was due to an exacerbation of asthma.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: I would like to prescribe an albuterol inhaler, 2 puffs every 4 hours as needed for wheezing or shortness of breath.
â€¢ Specialist Referral: I have referred him to pulmonology for an asthma workup.

Acid reflux.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: This seems stable.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: I recommended the patient continue Protonix.

Migraines.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: This problem is also stable. Continue on Imitrex as needed.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: I recommended he continue Imitrex as needed for migraines.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks or sooner if his conditions worsen.

 Shortness of breath.
 
 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 The patient is a 48-year-old female who presents for shortness of breath. She has a history of depression, smoking and chronic back pain.
 
 The patient reports shortness of breath with mild exercise and walking. She also notes some palpitations at times. She is not sure if it is due to her back pain or not. The patient states she has been exercising more. She continues to smoke but has decreased from two packs a day down to a couple of cigarettes daily.
 
 Regarding her depression, the patient feels that it is well managed on Effexor.
 
 Regarding her chronic back pain, the patient has been taking Neurontin, which she states is helping control her pain. She states she tries to get as much rest as she can. She is no longer doing yoga as she has not made it a habit.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 â€¢ Cardiovascular: Endorses dyspnea on exertion. Endorses palpitations.
 â€¢ Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath.
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain.
 â€¢ Integumentary:
 â€¢ Psychiatric: Endorses depression.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
 
 â€¢ Respiratory: Mild wheezes bilaterally.
 
 RESULTS
 
 Pulmonary function test demonstrates mild asthma and the appearance of COPD.
 
 X-ray of the chest demonstrates flattening of the diaphragm which is consistent with COPD.
 
 ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
 
 COPD.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: The patient presents today with shortness of breath with exertion. Her pulmonary function tests suggest asthma or COPD and her most recent chest x-ray and physical examination today are also consistent with COPD.
 â€¢ Patient Education and Counseling: I counseled the patient on the importance of smoking cessation.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: We will start the patient on Combivent, 2 puffs twice a day. I will also prescribe an albuterol inhaler, 2 puffs as needed, and a prednisone taper pack.
 
 Depression.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: It sounds like her depression is stable, so we will not change anything at this time.
 â€¢ Patient Education and Counseling: She will keep taking the Effexor. I encouraged her to practice yoga for depression relief as well as her back pain.
 
 Chronic back pain.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: The patient says she is doing well on Neurontin with only occasional exacerbation of the pain.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: She can continue Neurontin as is. I also encouraged her to practice yoga for her back pain.
 
 Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Logan Walker is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Mr. Walker reports that he was helping his daughter move some heavy equipment and lifted some heavy boxes a little too quickly on Saturday. He thought he heard a pop when he moved and he had to lie down for about an hour before his pain resolved. He has had stiffness ever since. The pain is located in his lower back. He took Tylenol, ibuprofen, and used Icy Hot on the area, but it did not seem to help. The patient endorses some tingling in his toes on his right foot, which resolved Sunday afternoon. He finds it difficult to find a comfortable position to sleep at night, and he tends to lie on his right side, which seems to help a little bit.

Regarding his diabetes type 2, Mr. Walker reports that he has not cooked a meal at home in weeks, due to travel. He notes that his diet has not been great, and he thinks he needs to eat clean for a couple of weeks.

He monitors his blood pressure at home and it is under control for the most part.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, Mr. Walker reports occasional aggravation of his knee when he runs too much or lifts boxes that are too heavy.

The patient denies chest pain, nausea, vomiting, fevers, and chills.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

â€¢ Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills.
â€¢ Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain and stiffness. Endorses knee pain with exertion.
â€¢ Neurological: Endorsed tingling in toes until Sunday, denies tingling today.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

â€¢ Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

VITALS REVIEWED

â€¢ Blood Pressure: Elevated

RESULTS

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

X-ray of the back is unremarkable. Normal bony alignment. No fracture present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Mr. Logan Walker is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with low back pain.

Lumbar strain.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: He injured his lower back while moving heavy boxes. His recent x-ray was unremarkable.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once a day.
â€¢ Specialist Referrals: Referral to physical therapy.
â€¢ Patient Education and Counseling: He was encouraged to continue icing the area and avoid strenuous activity.

Diabetes type 2.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: His recent hemoglobin A1c was elevated at 8. He does admit to some dietary indiscretion lately.
â€¢ Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day.

Hypertension.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: His blood pressures have been slightly elevated based on home monitoring and in clinic today.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg a day.

Osteoarthritis.
â€¢ Medical Reasoning: This is mostly well controlled.
â€¢ Medical Treatment: Continue to monitor the knee. No further work up is needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT
 
 Joint pain.
 
 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 The patient is a 26-year-old female with a past medical history significant for epilepsy, depression, and peptic ulcer disease who presents with some joint pain.
 
 The patient reports that her left elbow has really been bothering her. She states that she sits at her desk all day for work with her elbows bent. She reports that after work it is really hard for her to flex and extend her left elbow. She reports that it has been really stiff and painful. She also notes that she has noticed swelling on the olecranon of her elbow. She reports that she is right-handed, therefore, she can still write, which is great, but typing is difficult. She denies any numbness or tingling in her hands. She reports that she has some weakness in her arm but nothing too significant. She denies any fever or chills.
 
 Regarding her epilepsy, she reports that she has not had any recent seizures. She reports that her last seizure was a year ago. She reports that she is still taking Keppra.
 
 Regarding her depression, she reports that she started therapy last year and she is trying to avoid medications for this problem. She reports that therapy has been helpful, but she still feels down and stressed. She denies suicidal and homicidal ideations.
 
 Regarding her peptic ulcer, she reports that she was dealing with a lot of stress last year. She then underwent an endoscopy which showed that she had an episode of gastritis. She was subsequently diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease and started Protonix. She reports that she has not had any issues with her ulcer since the procedure and everything has been good.
 
 The patient denies chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. She reports that she does have a little bit of medial nasal congestion from allergies.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 â€¢ Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses medial nasal congestion from allergies.
 â€¢ Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
 â€¢ Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Endorses left elbow joint pain, swelling, and weakness.
 â€¢ Psychiatric: Endorses depression.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
 
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Examination of the left elbow reveals erythema and edema. Pain to palpation of the left olecranon. Warm to palpation. Pain with flexion and extension. Palpable left radial pulse.
 
 RESULTS
 
 Left arm x-ray does not reveal any evidence of elbow fracture.
 
 EGD revealed an episode of gastritis.
 
 ASSESSMENT
 
 Anna Morris is a 26-year-old female with a past medical history significant for epilepsy, depression, and peptic ulcer disease who presents with some joint pain.
 
 PLAN
 
 Left elbow pain.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: I believe she has left olecranon bursitis caused by repetitive trauma.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily.
 â€¢ Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to use a pillow to rest her arm on. She may also ice the area.
 
 Epilepsy.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: She has been doing well on Keppra and denies any recent seizures.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: Continue Keppra 500 mg twice a day. This was refilled today.
 
 Depression.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: She reports doing well with therapy.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: Initiate Lexapro 10 mg once daily.
 
 Peptic ulcer disease.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: Her recent endoscopy revealed gastritis
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: Continue Protonix 40 mg once daily before meals.
 
 Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 The patient is a 31-year-old female with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes, and hypertension who presents with abnormal labs. She had an insect bite at her last visit after hiking in the woods. We drew a Lyme titer which came back positive.
 
 The patient reports she has been feeling tired and lacking a lot of energy. She also notes swollen elbow joints, body aches, bullseye rash, and nausea. She states she has not been able to eat much. What she does eat has been bland foods such as crackers. She denies any high fevers.
 
 Regarding her type 2 diabetes, she states her blood sugars have been okay. She notes they are sometimes a little high or low, but nothing too far out of range. She is still taking metformin.
 
 Regarding her hypertension, she is monitoring her blood pressure at home and it has been good. She is avoiding salty foods and is still taking lisinopril.
 
 The patient denies abdominal pain and diarrhea.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 â€¢ Constitutional: Denies fevers. Endorses fatigue.
 â€¢ Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain and diarrhea. Endorses nausea.
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Endorses bilateral elbow joint swelling, pain. Endorses body aches.
 â€¢ Integumentary: Endorses a rash.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
 
 â€¢ Gastrointestinal: Examination of her abdomen reveals warmth to palpation. Nontender to palpation. No evidence of cellulitis.
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Swelling and pain to palpation of elbow joints bilaterally.
 â€¢ Integumentary: Small bullseye rash on the left abdominal quadrant.
 
 RESULTS
 
 Lyme titer: elevated.
 
 Labs: WBC is within normal limits. All other labs are normal as well.
 
 ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
 
 The patient is a 31-year-old female with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes, and hypertension who presents with abnormal labs.
 
 Newly diagnosed Lyme disease.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: This is a new issue for her. She presented with an insect bite at her last visit, and her subsequent lyme titer was elevated.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: I am going to prescribe doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 3 weeks. I am going to touch base with an infectious disease doctor to ensure nothing else that needs to be done. I want to see her again next week for follow-up for this.
 
 Hypertension.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: This has been well-controlled based on home monitoring. She has been compliant with dietary modifications including limiting her sodium intake.
 â€¢ Additional Testing: I am going to order a lipid panel.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: She will continue lisinopril 10 mg a day. This was refilled today.

 Diabetes type 2.

CHIEF COMPLAINT
 
 Back pain.
 
 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 
 Ms. Ramirez is a 34-year-old female with a past medical history significant for hypertension, who presents today with back pain.
 
 The patient reports she has been walking a lot lately, 30 minutes to an hour or so a day. While walking 6 days ago, she felt her back seize up on her. She is not sure what caused it but thinks she was walking a little faster than usual. She describes the sensation as a spasm. She has been taking ibuprofen and using heat on it but it is still pretty stiff. She denies any known trauma or injury to her back. She notes she has been weightlifting around 3 times a week. She did do deadlifts that day before her walk and thinks she may have been using her back more than her legs to lift. She locates the pain in her mid lower back. She denies any lower extremity numbness, tingling, and weakness.
 
 Regarding her hypertension, she states she has been doing readings at home and that has been looking great. She has been watching her diet which has helped. She is taking lisinopril.
 
 The patient endorses nasal congestion, which she attributes to her seasonal allergies.
 
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
 
 â€¢ Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion from seasonal allergies.
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Endorses bilateral low back pain and stiffness.
 â€¢ Neurological: Denies numbness.
 
 PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
 
 â€¢ Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
 â€¢ Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation along the right lateral aspect of her lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.
 
 RESULTS
 
 Back x-ray reveals good bony alignment with no obvious fracture.
 
 Labs: All within normal limits.
 
 ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
 
 Ms. Ramirez is a 34-year-old female with a past medical history significant for hypertension, who presents today with back pain.
 
 Back pain.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: She experienced a spasm-like pain in her back while walking approximately 6 days ago. She has also been lifting weights recently. Her lumbar spine x-ray was unremarkable and her recent labs were normal. I believe she has a lumbar strain.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: We will initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily.
 â€¢ Specialist Referrals: We will refer her to physical therapy to work on strengthening exercises.
 â€¢ Patient Education and Counseling: She may apply ice and heat to the area.
 
 Hypertension.
 â€¢ Medical Reasoning: This is well controlled with lisinopril and dietary modifications based on home monitoring.
 â€¢ Medical Treatment: She will continue lisinopril 10 mg daily. This was refilled today.
 â€¢ Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged her to continue with home monitoring and report any elevated blood pressures to me.
 
 Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.
